By 10:00 this morning, October 17,
two-way traffic on Ho Chi
Minh Road, the section passing through Phuoc Son district,
Quang Nam province, has returned to normal
after a short period of time.  The night was interrupted by an incident of a tractor-trailer overturning,
causing many vehicles to be
stuck. The incident occurred on the afternoon of September 16. The
tractor-trailer was driven by driver Le Van Thuan, born in
1993, residing in Tien Khanh district,
Dinh Binh province.  Going from Da Nang City
to C Tum, when reaching the section passing
Kham Duc town, Phuoc Son district, Quang Nam province, it
overturned immediately after the incident.
Phuoc Son district police promptly
arrived at the scene to separate the traffic.
traffic and sent emergency forces
regularly to warn of danger until
this morning. Rescue forces were sent to
deploy a rescue plan for tractors in
distress to relieve local traffic congestion
on the Ho Chi Minh route.
Today, the People's Committee of Tan An
Tay commune, Ngoc Hien district, Ca Mau province, confirmed that an
explosion on Cua Lon River had just occurred in the area,
leaving three workers missing.
According to initial information, people
saw three victims.  including a 42-year-old man, a 33-
year-old TVN and a 16-year-old NC living in a sa pho village in
Nam Can district, went on Vo Loi to the Cua Lon
river area under the authority of Tan An Tay commune
to search for scrap until about 9:30 on the same
day.  I heard a loud explosion. Then I
ran back to search. All three people were
missing. Only half of the
shell's head and tail were left.
Some evidence showed that there were explosions
on tree branches around the
scene.  Some human body parts were covered with fabric,
but at noon on the same day, Ngoc
Hien district authorities said
the area where the
explosion occurred that caused B worship to go missing has not yet been determined, and the
cause of the explosion is currently unknown to the police.  Ngoc
Hien district is verifying
relevant information to determine the location of the explosion on Cua Lon
River.
The dragon is the mascot of the year Giap
Thinh 2024 and in Vietnamese culture, the
dragon image is present in a variety of
aspects of social life.  Festivals from architecture,
costumes, applied arts, to
festival activities. On this occasion, the
Ho Chi Minh City Museum is introducing more than 100
precious dragon artifacts in an exhibition
titled Long Van Khanh Image Association.
Dragons in Vietnamese culture
Artifacts with dragon images
in Vietnamese culture from the Ly Dynasty to the
Nguyen Dynasty are divided into four
main contents dragons in the royal court dragons
in daily life dragons in
religious beliefs and dragons  The oldest architecture in
Asia is the
artifacts from the construction of the Thang Long Sutra
during the Ly Tran Dynasty. There, we
will see the earliest image of the dragon
and it went through many stages.
The artifacts that we consider
to be the most artistic are the
dragon-shaped artifacts of the
Nguyen Dynasty, the artifacts of the
Ho Chi Minh City Historical Museum and some
private collections that we want to
Introducing that is the image of the
Vietnamese dragon. How it has transformed
in each era with its
own characteristics to make it
most artistically perfect in the Nguyen Dynasty
as well as remind the public as well.
especially for young people, it is the
image of the dragon in their minds and
most especially, it is the image
of the grasshopper that reminds them of the
nation's roots. The exhibition will last until
the 31st.

this year. Peru has successfully recovered more than 200
ancient coinage artifacts. Some dating back
more than 2,000 years, they were returned from
collectors and  Private organizations in the US,
Germany, Belgium, Canada and
Spain that stand out among the K
Post items are knotted strings used
as calculation systems and dozens of
engravings about the culture of ca.
empire that dominated Peru from the 3rd to 16th centuries.
Artifacts also came from
other indigenous civilizations including the
chan cy and mu bird cultures. This was part of
Peru's efforts to reclaim these
Historically valuable artifacts have been
smuggled out of the country or stored in
international museums for decades.
This effort has brought back about 840
artifacts in the past two years.  A
